q: How can I check if it's dandruff?
a: Dandruff causes white or grey flakes of skin to appear on the scalp and in the hair. The flakes are often more noticeable in darker hair and if they fall from your scalp onto your shoulders. Your scalp may also feel dry and itchy.

q: What can I do to treat dandruff myself?
a: You can use an anti-dandruff shampoo to treat dandruff. Look for a shampoo that contains ingredients like zinc pyrithione, salicylic acid, selenium sulphide, ketoconazole, or coal tar. Use the shampoo for a month to see if your dandruff gets better.

q: When should I see a GP about my dandruff?
a: You should see a GP if you still have dandruff symptoms after using anti-dandruff shampoo for a month, if your dandruff is severe or your scalp is very itchy, if your scalp is red or swollen, or if you have flaky, itchy patches on your face or other parts of your body.

q: What are the possible causes of dandruff?
a: Dandruff is not caused by poor hygiene. It may be more noticeable if you do not wash your hair regularly. Stress and cold weather can also make dandruff worse. Other possible causes include seborrheic dermatitis, ringworm, eczema, contact dermatitis, and psoriasis.

q: What should I do if I'm not sure what's causing my dandruff?
a: If you're not sure what's causing your dandruff, you can follow the advice on this page and see a GP if things do not get better after a month.

q: What are the symptoms of dandruff?
a: The symptoms of dandruff include white or grey flakes of skin on the scalp and in the hair, dry and itchy scalp, and more noticeable flakes in darker hair.

a: You can treat dandruff yourself by using an anti-dandruff shampoo that contains ingredients such as zinc pyrithione, salicylic acid, selenium sulphide, ketoconazole, or coal tar. Use the shampoo for a month to see if it improves your dandruff.

q: What are the possible causes of dandruff?
a: Possible causes of dandruff include seborrheic dermatitis, ringworm, eczema, contact dermatitis, psoriasis, and cradle cap.

q: Should I worry if I'm not sure what's causing my dandruff?
a: No, you should not worry if you're not sure what's causing your dandruff. Follow the advice on this page and see a GP if your condition does not improve after a month.

q: Is dandruff contagious?
a: No, dandruff is not contagious.

q: Can stress worsen dandruff?
a: Yes, stress can worsen dandruff.

a: You should use an anti-dandruff shampoo that contains ingredients like zinc pyrithione, salicylic acid, selenium sulphide, ketoconazole, or coal tar.

q: Can dandruff cause hair loss?
a: Dandruff itself does not cause hair loss, but certain conditions like ringworm can cause both dandruff and hair loss.

q: What are the possible causes of scaly, itchy, and red patches on the skin?
a: Possible causes of scaly, itchy, and red patches on the skin include seborrheic dermatitis, tinea capitis (ringworm), eczema, contact dermatitis, and psoriasis.
